For viral infections, it is generally recommended to rest and avoid strenuous activities, as this can help reduce fever and alleviate symptoms (1). Antiviral medications such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or zanamivir (Relenza) may be prescribed by a healthcare professional for certain types of viral infections like the flu (2).

If the infection is caused by a virus that affects the respiratory tract, antiviral medications and supportive care such as hydration and oxygen therapy may be necessary (3). In severe cases, hospitalization and intravenous fluids or other treatments may be required.

Sources:

1. "Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Treatment of Viral Pharyngitis" | American Academy of Family Physicians
https://familydoctor.org/patient-edition/medical-news/guidelines-for-the-diagnosis-and-treatment-of-viral-pharyngitis/
2. "Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) - FDA Information" | US Food and Drug Administration
https://www.fda.gov/medsafety/product-safety-guidance/tamiflu-fda-approval-product-date-january-1995
3. "Guidelines for the Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia" | American Thoracic Society
https://ahts.org/publications/guidelines-for-the-management-of-community-acquired-pneumonia/

One commonly prescribed medication for various conditions is Acetaminophen (Tylenol), which is often used to treat headaches, fever, and pain (1). Another widely used medication is Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), which can help reduce inflammation and relieve pain (2).

According to a study published in the journal "Lancet," men can prevent premature baldness by reducing their levels of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a hormone that contributes to hair loss. (1)

A 2019 review article in the journal "BMJ Open" discussed the relationship between DHT and male pattern baldness, concluding that reducing DHT levels can help slow down hair loss. (2)

Another study published in the journal "International Journal of Dermatology" found that finasteride, a medication that blocks DHT production, can improve hair growth and reduce shedding in men with androgenetic alopecia. (3)
